content:
I'm new to lean4, and I have experience in programming with other language.
I just found that it's difficult to find whether a type is in a given typeclass or defined a "method" using namespace. how you guys do these things? searching the whole source code?
and is it possible that LSP of Lean4 can be ergonomic as rust-analyzer? showing a list in the type definition which is used to jump to where its implementations are
You can do #synth Add Nat, and the instance name pops up in the Infoview

There's also going to the mathlib docs (like https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Init/Prelude.html#Add) and clicking on the "instance" underneath to see the instances in the whole library (this includes core, batteries, and mathlib)
great! such html docs are maintained by users or generated by program?
Shen Weihao has marked this topic as resolved.
thanks! I thought such thing would be integrated in lake
It is, you add some lines to your lakefile and then you can build the documentation with lake (see the docgen readme)
I mean like an integrated command like lake doc
It's integrated as a lake facet, like lake build ModuleName:doc
